support.p: Rejected monument National Monuments Record of Wales (NPRN): 301072 Church of St Michael and All Angels
support.note: Described as sandstone...very fine-grained, homogenous, quartz dominated, mid-blue grey...the precise source of this lithology has not been established but it is similar to lithologies in walls local to the church (Edwards 2013, 311).
support.desc: There is a chi-ro cross carved on the top of the inscribed face.

supportDesc.condition: Macalister (1945, 372) notes that the left-hand angle has been chipped as though to destroy an ogham inscription. Edwards (2013, 311) mentions that there is some damage to the inscribed surface of the stone, but the carving and roman-letter inscription is in good condition.

layoutDesc.layout: Rhys (1907, 94-95) saw a potential fragmentary ogham inscription on the right edge of the inscribed face, however more recent assesments have classified the marks as natural (Edwards 2013, 313). The stone is inscribed with a roman-letter inscription in two lines reading vertically downwards, justified to the bottom. The roman-letter inscription is immediately below the cross.

handDesc.handNote: The ogam inscription does not survive so information on the execution of the letters. According to Macalister (1945, 373), the Latin inscription has been chiselled. Edwards (2013, 312) described the roman-letter inscription as medium incised and neatly but unevenly set out. The second line of the inscription begins towards the end of the first line. The inscription consists of several closely packed letters and capitals with miniscule S (Edwards 2013, 312)..

origin.origPlace: Treflys, Caithness, Wales 52.918011, -4.181561 National Grid Reference: SH 5342 3785
origin.origDate: Second half of the sixth century A.D.

history.provenance: The stone was discovered in 1904 during the demolition of the western part of the churchyard wall. The stone was found built into the foundations of the wall and moved to its present location after 1956. Rhys (1907, 94-95) was the first to suggest the possibility of an ogham inscription and to publish a reading.
In the church, standing against the wall in the north-east corner of the chancel (SH 5346 3785).

app.note: According to Edwards (2013, 313), Rhys (1907, 94-95) detected five notches and the ends of other possible strokes which he claimed might be a fragmentary ogham inscription.
Nash-Williams (Edwards 2013, 313) also suggested that there might be vestiges of ogham letters but did not supply a reading.

Edwards (2013, 313) confirms that the existence of an ogham inscription may be discounted given more recent investigations of the stone which determined that the marks which Rhys (1907, 94-95) and Nash-Williams (Edwards 2013, 313) observed bear little resemblance to ogham strokes or notches and should no longer be considered credible.

div.p: Ogham: No translation of the purported ogham inscription is offered

The first name in the roman-letter inscription, Iaconus is most likely a derivative of OI éo, gen. iach 'salmon'. Rhys (1907, 96) also suggested that it could be from *iakk- (W. iach, 'healthy', OI ícc. The most straightforward reading of the second name is, Firmin(i)us which was a popular Latin name seen elsewhere in Britain (Edwards 2013, 313).
